column5:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $1 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column13: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

Share of population in poverty, by pover: 40% of median - share of population below poverty line
column5:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 40% of the median.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

Share of population in poverty, by pover: Mean income or consumption per day
column5:
The mean level of income or consumption per day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

column5:
Number of people living in households with an income per person below $6.85 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5:
% of population living in households with an consumption per person below $40 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $1 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $1 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $2.15 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $2.15 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $3.65 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $3.65 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.

 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $6.85 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

% of population living in households with an income per person below $6.85 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an consumption per person below $6.85 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.

 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an consumption per person below $10 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an consumption per person below $20 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an consumption per person below $30 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below $40 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an consumption per person below $40 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $1 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below $1 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $2.15 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below $2.15 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $3.65 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $6.85 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $10 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $20 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $20 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below $20 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $30 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $30 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below $30 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $40 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below $40 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below $40 a day.
 
 The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 40% of the median.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 50% of the median.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 60% of the median.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an income per person below 60% of the median.
 
 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
% of population living in households with an consumption per person below 60% of the median.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below 40% of the median.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

Number of people living in households with an income per person below 40% of the median.
 
 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.

 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an consumption per person below 40% of the median.
 
 The data relates to consumption per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income per person below 50% of the median.
 
 The data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.

column5: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2023)
column7:
Number of people living in households with an income or consumption per person below 60% of the median.
 
 Depending on the country and year, the data relates to income measured after taxes and benefits, or to consumption, per capita. 'Per capita' means that the incomes of each household are attributed equally to each member of the household (including children).
 
 Non-market sources of income, including food grown by subsistence farmers for their own consumption, are taken into account.
 
 NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR
 
 For a small number of country-year observations, the World Bank PIP data contains two estimates: one based on income data and one based on consumption data. In these cases we keep only the consumption estimate in order to obtain a single series for each country.
 
 You can find the data with all available income and consumption data points, including these overlapping estimates, in our [complete dataset](https://github.com/owid/poverty-data#a-global-dataset-of-poverty-and-inequality-measures-prepared-by-our-world-in-data-from-the-world-banks-poverty-and-inequality-platform-pip-database) of the World Bank PIP data.
column10: World Bank (2023). Poverty and Inequality Platform (version 20230919_2017 and 20230919_2011) [Data set]. World Bank Group. https://pip.worldbank.org/. Accessed January 17, 2024.
